StringWithMarkup.String: Dimethyl sulfide was detected in 3 out of 63 industrial wastewater effluents in the US, concn in 2 waste streams <10 ug/L, concn in 1 waste stream >100 ug/L(1). Sampling conducted in 1982 reported dimethyl sulfide as detected in the influent and effluent of a Belgian wastewater treatment plant(2). 10-50% of the total volatile sulfur compounds emitted from a pulp mill with sulphate and semi-alkaline pulping processes were identified as dimethyl sulfide(3). Air and water samples were collected at a livestock raising site; dimethyl sulfide concns ranged from 0.0004 to 0.0059 ppm in the air to 0.031 to 1.47 in the wastewater from the site(4). Head space volatile samples from stored food exudate and garden waste contained dimethyl sulfide at unreported concns(5,6). Wort boiling during beer production results in the emission of dimethyl sulfide(7).

Reference: (1) Brack W et al; Env Tox Chem 17: 1982-91 (1998)
(2) Smet E et al; Atmos Env 33: 1295-1303 (1999)
(3) Andersson FAT et al; J Air Waste Manag Assoc 54: 855-61 (2004)
(4) Devai I, Delaune RD; Water Env Res 17: 203-08 (1999)
(5) Himberg K et al; Atmos Env 21: 1671-74 (1987)

StringWithMarkup.String: Dimethyl sulfide was detected in 3 of 4 aqueous leachate samples collected from three hazardous waste sites in Germany on unknown dates at concentrations ranging from 1000 to 24,000 ug/L, with an average of 9700 ug/L(1). Dimethyl sulfide was detected in an unknown number of air samples collected at an aerobic composting site in Belgium on an unknown date at a maximum concentration of 8.2 mg/cu m(2). Dimethyl sulfide was detected in 8 of 8 air emission samples collected at a biogas production plant in Linkoping, Sweden between November 2000 and May 2002 at concentrations ranging from 100 to 8770 ppb, with an average of 2700 ppb(3). After upgrading the pollution control processes at this biogas plant, dimethyl sulfide was detected in 3 of 6 air emission samples collected between November 2000 and May 2002 at concentrations ranging from 3 to 130 ppb, with an average of 51 ppb(3). Dimethyl sulfide was detected in an unknown number of air emission samples collected from three wastewater treatment plants in Baton Rouge, Louisiana on an unknown date at concentrations ranging from 0.007 to 51 ug/L, with a medium of 0.021 ug/L(4). Dimethyl sulfide was detected, but not quantified, in air emission samples collected from pulp mills in Finland on unknown dates(5).

Section.Description: Concentrations of this compound in sediment/soil.

Reference: (1) Whelan JK et al; Geochim Cosmo Acta 44: 1767-85 (1980)
(2) Roberts NJ, Burton HR; Chemosphere 29: 1627-1637 (1994)

StringWithMarkup.String: SEDIMENT: Dimethyl sulfide was detected in 1 of 10 sediment samples collected from Walvis Bay, Namibia, southwest Africa in Dec. 1975-Jan 1976 at a concentration of 5 ng/g dry sediment; the substance was only found at a depth of 32-36 cm below the bay bottom(1). Dimethyl sulfide was detected in 9 of 13 sediment samples collected in Antarctica lakes and basins on unknown dates at concentrations ranging from 2 to 124 ug/L, with an average concentration of 61 ug/L(2).

Reference: Sorensen J; Biogeochemistry 6 (3): 201-10 (1988)

StringWithMarkup.String: SEDIMENT: Seasonal variation of dimethyl sulfide was determined in sediment porewater from the freshwater section of a Danish estuary. Porewater was removed from the sediment core samples by pressure filtration and analyzed for dimethyl sulfide by gas chromatography. Detectable dimethyl sulfide levels of up to 0.1 uM were found only in the summer and only within the upper 5 cm of the sediment. The highest concentration of about 0.1 uM dimethyl sulfide was observed in late summer when a distinct subsurface max was formed. The dimethyl sulfide accumulation was probably associated with decomposing fragments of macro-algae in the surface layer.

Reference: (1) Farwell SO et al; Soil Biol Biochem 11: 411-5 (1979)
(2) Aneja VP; Air Waste Manag Assoc 40: 469-76 (1990)
(3) Cooper WJ et al; Atmos Environ 21: 1491-5 (1987)
(4) Kelly DP, Smith NA; Adv Microb Ecol 11: 345-85 (1990)

StringWithMarkup.String: SOIL: Dimethyl sulfide was detected in emissions from tidal marsh soil, an agricultural soil, and a forest soil(1). Maximum rate of dimethyl sulfide emissions from tidal marsh soil at field capacity, 0.2 ng S/min(1). Emission rates of dimethyl sulfide from coastal ecosystems ranged from 0.02 to 1.87 g sulfur/sq m-yr(2). Inland soils emitted dimethyl sulfide at rates from 0.0003 to 92.8 g sulfur/sq m-yr(2). Emissions of methyl disulfide from 5 wetland soils in Florida ranged from <0.02 to 10 ug sulfur/sq m-hr(3). Values for biogenic emissions of dimethyl sulfide from open oceans and marine environments range from 0.02 to 0.106 g sulfur/sq m-yr(2). Emission of dimethyl sulfide from oceanic sources, salt marshes, inland swamps, and soil and plants was measured as 38-40, 0.58, 0.84, and 0.2-0.4 Tg sulfur/yr(4).

Reference: (1) Adams DF et al; J Air Pol Cont Assoc 29: 380-83 (1979)
(2) Aneja V; J Air Waste Manag Assoc 40: 469-79 (1990)

StringWithMarkup.String: SOIL: Dimethyl sulfide was detected in 5 of 6 soil samples collected in Indiana, Ohio, North Carolina and Arkansas in September to November 1977 at annual flux concentrations ranging from 0.002 to 0.013 g/sq m/yr, with an average flux concentration of 0.0034 g/sq m/yr(1). Dimethyl sulfide was detected in 8 of 9 soil samples collected in North Carolina, Iowa, Ohio, Indiana and the eastern US on unknown dates at an annual flux concentrations of 0.0006 to 180 g/sq m/yr(2).

Reference: Staubes R, et al; Tellus 41B (3): 305-13 (1989)

StringWithMarkup.String: SOIL: Emission rates of the reduced sulfur gases, carbonyl sulfide, dimethyl sulfide and carbon disulfide, from 12 representative soils in Germany have been examined by means of a dynamic gas emission chamber. The compounds were sampled by cryogenic technique and measured by subsequent gas chromatography/flame photometric detector analysis. Besides soil type, soil temperature and moisture are the major factors controlling source strength. Dimethyl sulfide and carbonyl sulfide were the predominant gases emitted from organic soils. Dimethyl sulfide maximum emission rates reached 100 ng S/sq m/min. Measurements of the diurnal variations of emission rates show daily patterns of DMS and carbonyl sulfide emission rates which coincide with the soil temperature curve. The fraction of dimethyl sulfide emission from moist, low humus containing soils only amounts to 10 to 20% compared to 40 to 45% from dry soils. Sulfur fluxes of dimethyl sulfide from soil treated with liquid manure were enhanced by a factor of 5 to 6 compared to unfertilized soil of the same type.

StringWithMarkup.String: RURAL/REMOTE: Concns from 6 to 200 pg/l(1). Vertical distributions of dimethyl sulfide concns in maritime air west of Tasmania were monitored; in the mixed layer concns of 15-60 parts/trillion were seen with concns of <1 to 2.4 parts/trillion in the free troposphere(2). Avg concns of dimethyl sulfide in air above the Atlantic Ocean, the English Channel, and the North Sea were measured as 31.8 and 37.7 ng sulfur/cu m, 185 ng sulfur/cu m, and 105-561 ng sulfur/cu m, respectively(3). Dimethyl sulfide was measured at a remote location on the Isle of Lewis in NW Scotland; concns from 2 to 468 ng sulfur/cu m were reported(4). Concns of dimethyl sulfide in air from equatorial regions ranged from 3 to 46 ng sulfur/cu m (avg=18 ng sulfur/cu m); air from above the polar waters south of the Falkland Islands contained dimethyl sulfide at concns from 3 to 714 ng sulfur/cu m (avg=73 ng sulfur/cu m)(5). Avg boundary layer concns of dimethyl sulfide collected near the East Coast of the U.S. and from the vicinity of Bermuda were 27 and 54 parts/trillion vol, respectively(6). Concns of dimethyl sulfide in air above the North-East Atlantic (Azores), the Mid Atlantic Ocean (Bermuda), the Central Pacific, and the Northeast Pacific (on the Washington Coast) were 0.14, 0.13 (mean), 0.16-0.69, 0.01-0.74 ug/cu m, respectively(7). Concns of dimethyl sulfide in air above the North Pacific ranged from 4 to 694 ng sulfur/cu m(8). Maritime air masses off the northwest coast of the U.S., measured in 1985, contained dimethyl sulfide at typical concns of 0.3-1.2 and 0.01-0.12 nmol/cu m in the mixed layer and at 3.6 km, respectively(9). Mixed layer concns were consistent with surface water concns(9).

Reference: (1) Luria M et al; Atmos Env 23: 139-47 (1989)
(2) Putaud JP et al; Atmos Env 33: 647-59 (1999)
(3) Berresheim H; J Geophys Res (Atmos) 98: 12701-711 (1993)
(4) Davison B et al; Atmos Env 30: 1895-1906 (1996)

StringWithMarkup.String: RURAL/REMOTE: Dimethyl sulfide was detected in 7 of 11 air samples collected at 3000 meters above the Atlantic Ocean in the vicinity of Bermuda in June 1986 at concentrations ranging from 1 to 16 ng/cu m, with an average of 10 ng/cu m(1). At 90 meters above the ocean surface, dimethyl sulfide was detected in 11 of 11 air samples at concentrations ranging from 78-508 ng/cu m, with an average of 240 ng/cu m(1). Dimethyl sulfide was detected in 74 of 74 air samples collected at sea level above the North Atlantic ocean in the vicinity of Brittany, France between May and June 1993 at concentrations ranging from 0.31 to 7.8 mg/cu m, with an average of 1.6 mg/cu m(2). Dimethyl sulfide was detected in an unknown number of air samples collected 480 m above sea level over the northeastern Pacific coast in the vicinity of northern Washington state at concentrations ranging from 0.10 to 0.24 ppb(3). Dimethyl sulfide was detected in 23 of 23 air samples collected at the Antarctic Peninsula from November to December 1992 at concentrations ranging from 18 to 396 ng/cu m(4). Dimethyl sulfide was detected in 51 of 51 air samples collected at the east Weddell Sea near Antartica at concentrations ranging from 7.6 to 1390 ng/cu m, with an average of 198 ng/cu m(4); the highest levels were thought to be due to melting ice releasing dimethyl sulfide originally generated from algal growth.

StringWithMarkup.String: Dimethyl disulfide has been detected in the volatile components of Beaufort cheese(1), of strawberries(2), of mutton, chicken, beef and pork(3), and of cooked mussels(4). Dimethyl disulfide has been detected in samples of various dried legumes at the following concentrations: lima beans, 8.6-176.7 ppb; pinto beans, 17.3-25.3 ppb; red kidney beans, 26.9 ppb; black beans, 15.2 ppb; navy beans, 401.7 ppb; mung beans, 47.7 ppb; soybeans, 48.5 ppb; split peas, 8.0 ppb; and lentils, 10.5-53.6 ppb(5). Dimethyl sulfide has been detected in the volatiles from popped popcorn at a concentration of 70 ug/kg dry weight(6). StringWithMarkup.String: NIOSH (NOES Survey 1981-1983) has statistically estimated that 3,920 workers (200 of these were female) were potentially exposed to dimethyl sulfide in the US(1). Occupational exposure to dimethyl sulfide may occur through inhalation and dermal contact with this compound at workplaces where dimethyl sulfide is produced or used(SRC). The greatest potential for inhalation and dermal exposure to dimethyl sulfide is expected in chemical manufacturing sites in which this compound is used as a raw material or solvent. Monitoring data indicate that the general population may be exposed to dimethyl sulfide via inhalation of ambient air, ingestion of food, and dermal contact with this compound in seawater or contaminated wastewater(SRC).

StringWithMarkup.String: Dimethyl sulfide was detected in expired air from 54 carefully selected healthy, nonsmokers as follows: 387 samples, 41.6% pos, mean concn 0.99 ng/l(1). Reference.Name: GHS Classification Tree
Reference.Description: The United Nations' Globally Harmonized System of Classification and Labeling of Chemicals (GHS) provides a harmonized basis for globally uniform physical, environmental, and health and safety information on hazardous chemical substances and mixtures. It sets up criteria for the classification of chemicals for physical-chemical, health, and environmental hazards of chemical substances and mixtures and sets up standardized hazard information to facilitate global trade of chemicals.  Please note that obsolete codes are added in this classification for completeness purposes, as they are still in use. Any obsolete codes are annotated as such.

Reference.Name: EPA SRS List Classification
Reference.Description: Substance Registry Services (SRS) is the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) central system for information about substances that are tracked or regulated by EPA or other sources. It is a resource for basic information about chemicals, biological organisms, and other substances of interest to EPA and its state and tribal partners. SRS makes it possible to identify which EPA data systems, environmental statutes, or other sources have information about a substance and which synonym is used by that system or statute.

Reference.Name: EPA TSCA Classification
Reference.Description:
EPA Chemicals under the Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA) collection contains information on chemicals and their regulation under TSCA. The chemical classification tree is created based on the TSCA substance regulatory flag, UVCB, and commercial activity status.
Update: 2024-12-06 12:51:01

Reference.Name: MolGenie Organic Chemistry Ontology
Reference.Description: An organic chemistry ontology developed by MolGenie and OntoChem to assign chemical entities to structural classes, split into three main subsections: calculated properties, compounds and substructural concepts. The ontology contains chemistry structural classes with a focus on elements and small organic compounds, but not inorganic, polymer, biopolymer, metal complexes, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) and other chemistry entities. The ontology has been mapped to several collections of chemicals, including (a) Chemicals of Biological Interest (ChEBI), (b) the ChEMBL database of bioactive molecules, (c) the LOTUS natural product collection, (d) per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) extracted from Barnabas et al (2022) DOI: 10.1039/D2DD00019A (e) PubChemLite and (f) the ZeroPM Global Chemical Inventory.
Reference.LicenseNote: CC-BY 4.0
